name: Bite, Bat, Raccoon, Skunk
summary: This document provides guidelines for managing bite wounds from bats, raccoons, and skunks, with a primary focus on the risk of rabies and bacterial infection.
description: The document outlines the clinical setting for bites from animals that are potential rabies vectors. It specifies the common bacterial etiologies and provides primary and alternative antibiotic regimens. A significant emphasis is placed on the presumption of rabies and the necessity of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP), as well as tetanus vaccination.

syndromes.name: Bite Wound from Potential Rabies Vector
syndromes.description: A bite wound from an animal such as a bat, raccoon, or skunk, which carries a high risk of transmitting rabies in addition to bacterial pathogens.

special_considerations: Animals such as bats, raccoons, and skunks are considered potentially rabid unless testing of the euthanized animal proves negative.
Raccoons, skunks, foxes, and most other carnivores, as well as bats, should be presumed rabid unless definitively proven negative by lab testing.
Administer tetanus toxoid or Tdap (preferred) if > 10 years have passed since the last dose.
See "Rabies, Vaccines and PEP" for detailed evaluation procedures and recommendations.

pathogens.name: Streptococcus sp.
pathogens.summary: A common bacterial pathogen found in animal bite wounds.

pathogens.name: Staphylococcus sp.
pathogens.summary: Another common bacterial pathogen that can cause infection following a bite.

pathogens.name: Rabies virus
pathogens.summary: A fatal virus transmitted through the saliva of infected animals. Post-exposure prophylaxis is critical.
